author.name: Eric Weinstein
author.description: Dad.

html:
What is the most boring sounding book that changed & improved your life immeasurably?

Three candidates from my life that, frustratingly, I can’t generically recommend to friends:

A) Einstein Manifolds by Besse.
B) Turkish Grammar by Underhill
C) Science Since Babylon by Price.

author.name: Alan Laidlaw
author.description: Too academic for business, too business for academia.

html: @Prigoose The technology we use today is not very different from tech 1000s of years ago. Perspectival devices helped us see parts of the world, divided into grids, making it easier to replicate a version of reality into a surface. (👈 a belief of mine that leads to several principles.) https://t.co/GVal9JHsLY

author.name: sarv
author.description: Rabbit-hole diver | CS + Cogsci @UCBerkeley | prev @replit @pioneerdotapp

html: I’ve been thinking about what computers would look like without screens. How can we make them more ambient and less shitty and distracting?\n\nHere’s a lil device that prints my daily schedule in the morning so I don’t need to open my phone to look at my calendar. https://t.co/aYShDnyeyj

author.name: Codex OS

html: I’ve been thinking about what computers would look like without screens. How can we make them more ambient and less shitty and distracting?\n\nHere’s a lil device that prints my daily schedule in the morning so I don’t need to open my phone to look at my calendar. https://t.co/aYShDnyeyj

author.name: sarv
author.description: Rabbit-hole diver | CS + Cogsci @UCBerkeley | prev @replit @pioneerdotapp

html: A fantastic thought experiment is to imagine what tech would look like without screens. \n\nI think this fixes so much about what's wrong with tech. No obsessively staring at tiny windows, but more ambient interfaces that meld into the 'real world'.

author.name: Andy Matuschak
author.description: More wonder, more insight, more capacity, more joy!\n\nCurrently exploring tools that augment human memory and attention.

html: The VR bit is just a sleight of hand: both groups end up teaching a bot. But putting the environment in VR makes it possible for one group to believe they're teaching a human. That group ends up learning the material they're teaching much better!\n\nhttps://t.co/aHn72atcbD

author.name: Andy Matuschak
author.description: More wonder, more insight, more capacity, more joy!\n\nCurrently exploring tools that augment human memory and attention.

html: Reminds me, tangentially, of a nice point from a conversation with @tayroga: recording your screen to hold yourself accountable feels utterly different emotionally from recording your screen to teach or explain something to someone else. (Much worse!)

author.name: Andy Matuschak
author.description: More wonder, more insight, more capacity, more joy!\n\nCurrently exploring tools that augment human memory and attention.

html: The schtick: after studying the material, the subject is intro'd to a fellow student (confederate!). They play Operation while "waiting their turn"…then the "lesson" occurs—in VR. One condition's told they're teaching the peer they met; the other believes they're teaching a bot.

author.name: Michael Warburton
author.description: Actor (All About Eve to Coronation Street), Cinephile, Drummer. Posting stuff I like, no pandering. Weekly column on Movies at https://t.co/FitXwVCTqK
